page.title: 04NEWTON HALL.
page.content: Situated near to the{River Tame}in Hyde,the importance of Newton Hall lies in the fact that the surviving 14th C.{cruck-framed}structure has the {largest span}of any such building in existence.In 1968,destruction of the site seemed imminent until the local engineering firm of{Messrs.William {Kenyon & Sons}stepped in to rescue the building.Working under the supervision of Dr.T.L.Marsden,builders completely restored the hall,using,as far as possible,{traditional tools,materials {and methods.}The reconstructed{cruck {blades}were cut from an oak found in Bury-St-Edmonds,as no such tree of the necessary size could be found in the North West of England.
